questions.text: A 26-year-old male came to dermatology OPD with complaints of hair loss for 3 months. On examination M-shaped receding hairline is seen with thinning of hair on the vertex. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Androgenic alopecia The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Androgenic alopecia. It is the most common cause of non-scarring alopecia. Androgenic alopecia aka Patterned type non-cicatricial alopecia Factors: Genetic + Androgens which lead to Shortening of the anagen phase Miniaturisation of hair follicle Treatment: Minoxidil Finasteride Platelet-rich plasma therapy Hair transplant

Highyeild:

Androgenic alopecia Male patterned hair loss Female patterned hair loss -Frontotemporal recession ( M-shaped recession) -Balding of vertex -Loss of hair over the central portion of the scalp - Frontal line maintained Hamilton-Norwood grading used Ludwig’s grading used

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Alopecia areata: It is an autoimmune disease with patchy hair loss. The hair follicles surrounding the patches on microscopy show an exclamation mark sign. Option C. Tinea capitis: It is a fungal infection that can be non-inflammatory (Ectothrix: Grey patch and Endothrix: black dot) or inflammatory type (favus, kerion) Option D. Anagen effluvium: It is a disorder in which the hair follicles in the anagen phase of the hair cycle are shed off. It is commonly seen after chemotherapy. The hair cycle gets arrested.

Extraedge:

MC cause of scarring alopecia: Lichen planopilaris, DLE MC cause of Nonscarring alopecia: Androgenetic alopecia

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient presented with severe diffuse hair fall for the last 1 month. She had a major accident with severe blood loss 5 months back for which she had to be hospitalized for 1 month. She is very anxious that all her hair will fall. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Telogen effluvium The given clinical history is suggestive of Telogen effluvium. A common cause of temporary hair loss due to excessive shedding of resting hair ( Telogen hair) after a major stress. Pathogenesis: The new hair comes up through the scalp and push out the resting club hairs. So, paradoxically, this type of hair loss is a sign of hair regrowth. Can occur in an age group and both sexes Feature: Non-scarring, diffuse hair loss No clinical or histological evidence of inflammation Can affect up to 50% of scalp hair Chronic Telogen effluvium usually accompanies chronic illness

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Alopecia areata: It is an autoimmune disease with patchy hair loss. The hair follicles surrounding the patches on microscopy show an exclamation mark sign. Option C. Anagen effluvium: It is a disorder in which the hair follicles in the anagen phase of the hair cycle are shed off. It is commonly seen after chemotherapy. The hair cycle gets arrested. Option D. Androgenic alopecia: Usually have recession of the frontal temporal hairline, leading to bald patches on the vertex scalp.

questions.text: A male patient presents with patchy hair loss with normal-looking skin on the scalp as shown. The trichogram shows an exclamation mark sign. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alopecia areata The given clinical picture is showing a circular patch of complete hair loss and no visible s igns of inflammation is suggestive of Alopecia areata

Highyeild:

It is an autoimmune disorder that causes reversible, non-scarring, patchy alopecia Targets: Anagen hair bulb Often associated with other autoimmune disorders like: Autoimmune thyroiditis, vitiligo, atopic dermatitis, lichen planus Features: The circular patch of complete hair loss No visible sign of inflammation Trichogram- Exclamation mark hair: Distal broad end and Proximal tapered end Going white overnight- Lymphocytes directed against melanin i n hair bulb: loss of pigmented hair with sparing of white/grey hairs Nail finding: Uniform, regular, geometric pitting Histopathology: Swarm of bees appearance: Inflammatory infiltrate consisting mainly of T cells in and around the bulbs of anagen follicle. Bad prognostic factors for alopecia areata: Early onset Patterns present: Occipital hair loss, Alopecia totalis, Alopecia universalis Associated with Atopy and autoimmune diseases

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A .Tinea capitis: It is a fungal infection that can be non-inflammatory (Ectothrix: Grey patch and Endothrix: black dot) or inflammatory type (favus, kerion) Option B. Cicatricial alopecia: It is aka scarring alopecia,” encompasses a group of hair loss disorders in which the hair follicle is irreversibly destroyed and replaced by fibrous tissue. Option D. Telogen effluvium: Non-scarring, diffuse alopecia that follows major stress like surgery or major illness.

Extraedge:

Nail pitting Psoriasis: Deep, coarse, irregular depressions in the nail plate Alopecia areata: Uniform, regular geometric pitting

questions.text: A patient presents with several patches of non-scarring alopecia on occipital and temporal regions. Histopathology shows several empty follicles with perifollicular infiltrates as well as pieces of broken hair with few hemorrhages. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trichotillomania The given clinical scenario of non-scarring alopecia on the occipital and temporal region ( sites accessible by hand ) with characteristic HPE findings and perifollicular haemorrhag e is suggestive of Trichotillomania.

Highyeild:

Trichotillomania Aka trichotillosis or hair-pulling disorder A disorder characterised by the irresistible urge to pull one’s own hair accompanied by a sense of relief leading to patchy, non-scarring alopecia. Age: Pre-school or early adolescence Features: Incomplete loss of hair within the patch Bizzare pattern Hair of varying length Perifollicular hemorrhage present The site of hair pulling may change over time but usually on the same side of the dominant hand -at the vertex, occiput “Friar tuck” distribution or “Tonsure pattern”: Plucking activity are centrifugal from a single starting point or linear, in a wave-like activity. Complication: Trichobezoar Treatment: Behavioural therapy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Alopecia areata: It is an autoimmune disease with patchy hair loss. The hair follicles surrounding the patches on microscopy show an exclamation mark sign. Option B. Lichen planus: It causes a scarring type of alopecia Option D. Loose anagen syndrome: It is due to defective keratinisation of the inner root sheath, rather than the hair shaft itself. The loose hair shaft can be easily pulled out of the follicle, leaving localised or diffuse bald areas of the scalp.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the hair cycle?

options.label: A
options.text: Telogen is responsible for the final length of hair

options.label: B
options.text: Only 1% of hair is in anagen at any point in time

options.label: C
options.text: Anagen hairs have a white bulb

options.label: D
options.text: Lower part of the hair follicle involutes during catagen

questions.correct_answer: D. Lower part of the hair follicle involutes during catagen
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lower part of the hair follicle involutes during catagen Phases of hair cycle: The anagen phase is when the hair grows —the hair follicle forms a new hair shaft. The catagen phase follows the anagen stage. This is the catabolic phase where the hair prepares itself for subsequent hair fall. The telogen phase is the Resting phase which follows the catagen phase. Ketogen is the phase of latency

questions.text: A male patient presents with patchy loss of hair on scalp, eyebrows, and beard. He has also history of rapid greying of hair in a few areas. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alopecia areata Patchy hair loss is suggestive of alopecia areata. Rapid greying of hair is also a clue in this question for alopecia areata.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Anagen effluvium is seen with chemotherapy due to stoppage of the dividing phase of the hair. It is not a patchy alopecia. It creates diffuse hair loss which is non scarring. Option C. Telogen effluvium is seen with nutritional disorders, hypothyroidism, anemia and after recent infections like fever. It creates diffuse non scarring alopecia. Option D. Androgenetic alopecia creates patterned hair loss (diffuse). In males it creates, frontal and parietal balding with preservation of lateral and posterior scalp. In females it presents as widening of the central parting.

questions.text: A male child presents with focal alopecia and boggy swelling on scalp and easily pluckable hair. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tinea capitis The clue in the question is a child with easily pluckable hair. This points to a diagnosis of tinea capitis. Focal alopecia and boggy swelling points to a diagnosis of a variant of tinea capitis which is kerion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- alopecia areata would not have boggy swelling and easily pluggable hair though it would also have focal alopecia Option B- patterned alopecia is the other name for androgenetic alopecia. It would have a diffuse loss and not of focal alopecia. It has thinning of hair without easily pluckable feature Option C- Telogen effluvium would also have a diffuse hair loss without focal allocation.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of cicatrizing alopecia except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trichotillomania Trichotillomania is an example of non scarring alopecia due to habitual pulling of scalp hairs.

Highyeild:

All causes of scarring alopecia Lichen planopilaris DLE Linear scalp morphoea SLE Chronic folliculitis Tinea capitis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Lichen planus will cause scarring alopecia. The clinical appearance is patchy scarring alopecia without scales. Option B- DLE will cause scarring alopecia with red scaly areas on sun exposed skin and loss of hair. The scales are called carpet tac scales. Option D- Tinea capitis of the inflammatory type (kerion/favus) causes scarring alopecia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with complaints of patchy hair loss over the scalp since the last 3 years. His patches were showing atrophy, wrinkling, and scarring. There was lack of follicles on biopsy. He also had non scaly flexural skin lesions. Which of the following histopathology findings are not expected from his skin lesions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Parakeratosis Parakeratosis would be seen in psoriasis which would not be having scarring alopecia. Scarring alopecia along with non scaly flexural lesions would point to a diagnosis of lichen planus.

Highyeild:

Scalp lichen planus An autoimmune causes of scarring alopecia involving the scalp creating irregular patches of hair loss footprint in snow appearance clinically slow progression with the long course may or may not be associated with skin features of lichen planus
